6.question: What do double solid yellow lines in the middle of the road indicate?

options.text: You may not pass over these lines unless entering/exiting a driveway or making a U-turn
You may pass if traffic is clear
options.explanation: Double solid yellow lines indicate no passing from either direction.

options.text: You may cross to make a left turn only during daylight hours
options.explanation: Time of day does not affect the rules for double yellow lines.

options.text: These lines are only advisory and may be crossed at any time
options.explanation: Double solid yellow lines are regulatory, not advisory.

6.question: What does a single solid white line indicate?

options.text: It marks traffic lanes going in the same direction
It marks the center of a road with two-way traffic
options.explanation: Yellow lines mark the center of a road with two-way traffic, not white lines.

options.text: It indicates you can pass when safe
options.explanation: A broken yellow line indicates when passing is allowed, not a solid white line.

options.text: It separates regular lanes from carpool lanes
options.explanation: Double solid white lines separate regular lanes from carpool lanes, not a single solid white line.

6.question: When making a right turn, you should:

options.text: Drive close to the right edge of the road
Begin the turn from the center of the intersection
options.explanation: You should start a right turn from the right lane, not the center of the intersection.

options.text: Always use the center lane
options.explanation: Right turns should be made from the right-most lane, not the center lane.

options.text: Move to the left side of your lane
options.explanation: For a right turn, you should be positioned on the right side of your lane, not the left.

6.question: What is the proper technique for parallel parking?

options.text: Pull alongside the vehicle in front of the space, back in at a 45-degree angle, then straighten out
Drive straight into the space head-on
options.explanation: Parallel parking requires backing into the space, not driving in head-on.

options.text: Back into the space without checking your blind spots
options.explanation: Always check your blind spots before backing into a parallel parking space.

options.text: Pull past the space, then drive forward into it
options.explanation: Proper parallel parking involves backing into the space, not driving forward into it.

6.question: When parking on a hill with your vehicle facing downhill, you should:

options.text: Turn your front wheels into the curb or toward the side of the road
Turn your front wheels away from the curb
options.explanation: When facing downhill, turn wheels toward the curb, not away from it.

options.text: Keep your wheels straight
options.explanation: When parking on a hill, you should turn your wheels in the appropriate direction, not keep them straight.

options.text: Turn your front wheels parallel to the curb
options.explanation: When facing downhill, turn wheels toward the curb, not parallel to it.

6.question: What does a broken yellow line in the center of the road indicate?

options.text: You may pass if the broken line is next to your driving lane and it is safe to do so
No passing is allowed from either direction
options.explanation: A broken yellow line indicates passing is allowed when safe, not that passing is prohibited.

options.text: You may cross to make a U-turn only
options.explanation: A broken yellow line allows passing when safe, not just for U-turns.

options.text: The line separates traffic moving in the same direction
options.explanation: Yellow lines separate traffic moving in opposite directions, not the same direction.

6.question: What is the purpose of a center left turn lane?

options.text: To prepare for and make a left turn or U-turn
To pass slower moving vehicles
options.explanation: Center left turn lanes are not for passing other vehicles.

options.text: To drive in when traffic is congested
options.explanation: Center left turn lanes should not be used as regular travel lanes during congestion.

options.text: To serve as an additional lane for emergency vehicles only
options.explanation: Center left turn lanes are not reserved exclusively for emergency vehicles.

6.question: How far may you legally drive in a center left turn lane?

options.text: 200 feet
500 feet
options.explanation: The legal limit for driving in a center left turn lane is 200 feet, not 500 feet.

options.text: 1000 feet
options.explanation: The legal limit for driving in a center left turn lane is 200 feet, not 1000 feet.

options.text: There is no distance limit
options.explanation: The legal limit for driving in a center left turn lane is 200 feet.

6.question: When is it legal to drive in a bicycle lane?

options.text: When parking, entering/leaving the road, or within 200 feet of making a turn
Whenever traffic is congested
options.explanation: Traffic congestion does not allow you to drive in a bicycle lane.

options.text: During late night hours when bicyclists are not present
options.explanation: Time of day does not change the rules for bicycle lanes.

options.text: Only when directed to by a law enforcement officer
options.explanation: You can legally drive in a bicycle lane in several situations without police direction.

6.question: What should you do if you need to make a left turn at a T intersection from a one-way street onto a two-way street?

options.text: You may turn from the center lane
You must turn from the far left lane only
options.explanation: At a T intersection, you can turn left from the center lane of a one-way street.

options.text: You must turn from the right lane
options.explanation: Left turns should not be made from the right lane at a T intersection.

options.text: You can turn from any lane
options.explanation: You cannot turn left from any lane, only from the center or left lane at a T intersection.

6.question: When making a left turn against a red light, when is it legal to proceed?

options.text: When turning from a one-way street onto a one-way street after stopping and yielding
Never, you must always wait for a green light to turn left
options.explanation: You may turn left against a red light when turning from a one-way street onto a one-way street.

options.text: When there is no traffic coming in either direction
options.explanation: The only time you can turn left on red is from a one-way street onto a one-way street.

options.text: When turning left from any street onto a one-way street
options.explanation: You can only turn left on red when turning from a one-way street onto a one-way street.

6.question: What does a double solid white line indicate?

options.text: A lane barrier that you should not cross
A regular lane marking that can be crossed at any time
options.explanation: Double solid white lines indicate a lane barrier that should not be crossed.

options.text: A division between opposing traffic
options.explanation: Yellow lines divide opposing traffic, not white lines.

options.text: A marking for pedestrian crossings
options.explanation: Double solid white lines indicate lane barriers, not pedestrian crossings.

6.question: When turning left, how should you position your wheels while waiting for oncoming traffic to clear?

options.text: Keep your wheels pointed straight ahead until it is safe to start your turn
Turn your wheels to the left so you're ready to turn
options.explanation: Keeping wheels straight prevents you from being pushed into oncoming traffic if rear-ended.

options.text: Turn your wheels to the right for safety
options.explanation: Wheels should be straight when waiting to turn left, not pointed right.

options.text: The direction of your wheels doesn't matter
options.explanation: Wheel direction is important for safety when waiting to turn left.

6.question: When merging onto a highway, you should:

options.text: Be at or near the speed of traffic and merge into a space large enough for your vehicle
Come to a complete stop first, then enter traffic
options.explanation: Stopping is dangerous unless absolutely necessary; match traffic speed instead.

options.text: Always maintain your current speed regardless of traffic
options.explanation: You should adjust your speed to match the flow of traffic when merging.

options.text: Force your way into traffic, as you have the right-of-way
options.explanation: Highway traffic has the right-of-way, not merging vehicles.

6.question: When parking at a blue curb, what is required?

options.text: A disabled person parking placard or special license plate
Payment at a parking meter
options.explanation: Blue curbs are for disabled parking only, not general paid parking.

options.text: A commercial vehicle license
options.explanation: Blue curbs are for disabled parking, not commercial vehicles.

options.text: No special requirements; anyone can park there
options.explanation: Blue curbs are reserved for vehicles with disabled person placards or plates.

6.question: How should you position your vehicle when driving in traffic lanes?

options.text: Stay in one lane as much as possible
Weave in and out of traffic to find the fastest lane
options.explanation: Weaving increases collision risk and is discouraged.

options.text: Drive straddling the lane line to have more options
options.explanation: You should stay fully within your lane, not straddle lane lines.

options.text: Change lanes frequently to avoid being boxed in
options.explanation: Constant lane changing increases risk; stay in one lane when possible.

6.question: What is illegal when parking your vehicle?

options.text: Parking within 15 feet of a fire hydrant
Parking within 30 feet of a stop sign
options.explanation: The handbook does not specify parking within 30 feet of a stop sign as illegal.

options.text: Parking with your right wheels within 18 inches of the curb
options.explanation: Parking within 18 inches of the curb is legal, not illegal.

options.text: Parking in the direction of traffic flow
options.explanation: Parking in the direction of traffic flow is required, not illegal.

6.question: When backing up in a straight line, you should:

options.text: Back up slowly while maintaining control and checking for hazards
Back up quickly to minimize time spent in reverse
options.explanation: Backing up should be done slowly with control, not quickly.

options.text: Look only in your rearview mirror
options.explanation: You should check all mirrors and blind spots, not just the rearview mirror.

options.text: Back up without signaling since you're not changing lanes
options.explanation: You should activate your turn signal before pulling up to the curb, then cancel it.

6.question: What should you do when exiting a highway?

options.text: Signal about 5 seconds (approximately 400 feet) before the exit
Wait until the last moment to signal your exit
options.explanation: You should signal well in advance, about 5 seconds before your exit.

options.text: Slow down significantly while still in the through lane
options.explanation: Maintain your speed until you enter the exit lane, then slow down gradually.

options.text: Cross over solid lines to reach your exit if necessary
options.explanation: Do not cross over solid lines when exiting; plan ahead to be in the proper lane.

6.question: What does a yield line (solid white line of triangles) indicate?

options.text: Where approaching vehicles should yield or stop
A bicycle crossing
options.explanation: Yield lines indicate where vehicles should yield or stop, not bicycle crossings.

options.text: A pedestrian-only walkway
options.explanation: Yield lines indicate where vehicles should yield or stop, not pedestrian-only walkways.

options.text: A prohibited driving area
options.explanation: Yield lines indicate where vehicles should yield or stop, not prohibited driving areas.
